content.body: Hello everyone
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Hello everyone

content.body: Wanted to ask one question that has been troubling me for a while?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Wanted to ask one question that has been troubling me for a while?

content.body: Back in the day, W3C had three divisions of the DOM spec. One was core DOM, the other was HTML DOM and the third was XML DOM. But when I go to the WHATWG spec, there is no mention of this distinction. My point is, that is this distinction still made in the specs of the DOM or can we now safely assume that there is no such distinction and that there is just one DOM spec.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Back in the day, W3C had three divisions of the DOM spec. One was core DOM, the other was HTML DOM and the third was XML DOM. But when I go to the WHATWG spec, there is no mention of this distinction. My point is, that is this distinction still made in the specs of the DOM or can we now safely assume that there is no such distinction and that there is just one DOM spec.

content.body: The Freelancer: there's no XML DOM vs HTML DOM anymore, though the behavior of some APIs differ between HTML and XML. It's just the DOM spec, and some things that were previously in the "HTML DOM" spec is now in the HTML spec
content.formatted_body: The Freelancer: there's no XML DOM vs HTML DOM anymore, though the behavior of some APIs differ between HTML and XML. It's just the DOM spec, and some things that were previously in the "HTML DOM" spec is now in the HTML spec

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: The Freelancer: there's no XML DOM vs HTML DOM anymore, though the behavior of some APIs differ between HTML and XML. It's just the DOM spec, and some things that were previously in the "HTML DOM" spec is now in the HTML spec

The Freelancer: there's no XML DOM vs HTML DOM anymore, though the behavior of some APIs differ between HTML and XML. It's just the DOM spec, and some things that were previously in the "HTML DOM" spec is now in the HTML spec

content.body: e.g. `createElement` and `createCDATASection`
content.formatted_body: e.g. createElement and createCDATASection

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: e.g. `createElement` and `createCDATASection`
e.g. createElement and createCDATASection

content.body: zcorpan: So if some other vendor, or let's say a library author for another language such as Python, wants to implement the DOM, they have to go through the WHATWG spec. Is that right? But then how would that person be able to distinguish between what's really meant for HTML, what's meant for XML, and what's meant for both. I hope you get my point.
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: So if some other vendor, or let's say a library author for another language such as Python, wants to implement the DOM, they have to go through the WHATWG spec. Is that right? But then how would that person be able to distinguish between what's really meant for HTML, what's meant for XML, and what's meant for both. I hope you get my point.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: zcorpan: So if some other vendor, or let's say a library author for another language such as Python, wants to implement the DOM, they have to go through the WHATWG spec. Is that right? But then how would that person be able to distinguish between what's really meant for HTML, what's meant for XML, and what's meant for both. I hope you get my point.

zcorpan: So if some other vendor, or let's say a library author for another language such as Python, wants to implement the DOM, they have to go through the WHATWG spec. Is that right? But then how would that person be able to distinguish between what's really meant for HTML, what's meant for XML, and what's meant for both. I hope you get my point.

content.body: The Freelancer: if they don't support HTML, then they can no-op the parts that branch off of an HTML check
content.formatted_body: The Freelancer: if they don't support HTML, then they can no-op the parts that branch off of an HTML check

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: The Freelancer: if they don't support HTML, then they can no-op the parts that branch off of an HTML check
The Freelancer: if they don't support HTML, then they can no-op the parts that branch off of an HTML check

content.body: Sorry, but I didn't get that.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Sorry, but I didn't get that.

content.body: Sorry, jargon :) no-op means no operation, meaning code that does nothing (or no code)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Sorry, jargon :) no-op means no operation, meaning code that does nothing (or no code)

content.body: For example, when implementing https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-document-createelement , if "this" can never be an HTML document (because HTML is not supported), then you can skip step 2
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: For example, when implementing https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-document-createelement , if "this" can never be an HTML document (because HTML is not supported), then you can skip step 2

content.body: Ok, so that means that any person wanting to implement the DOM for HTML or non-HTML documents has to nonetheless go through the whole document filtering out what he/she really needs?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Ok, so that means that any person wanting to implement the DOM for HTML or non-HTML documents has to nonetheless go through the whole document filtering out what he/she really needs?

content.body: Am I right?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Am I right?

content.body: yes
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: yes

content.body: One more thing, sorry to disturb you again and again, what was the motivation behind unifying these three DOM specifications (i.e. HTML DOM, XML DOM, and Core DOM)?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: One more thing, sorry to disturb you again and again, what was the motivation behind unifying these three DOM specifications (i.e. HTML DOM, XML DOM, and Core DOM)?

content.body: Browser engines is the primary implementer for web specs, and they have a single implementation of the DOM, not 3
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Browser engines is the primary implementer for web specs, and they have a single implementation of the DOM, not 3

content.body: It's easier to have a well-defined easy-to-implement spec if the behavior of an API is in one algorithm, instead of spread out across different documents
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It's easier to have a well-defined easy-to-implement spec if the behavior of an API is in one algorithm, instead of spread out across different documents

content.body: That sounds relatable :)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That sounds relatable :)

content.body: One last thing if you don't mind. May I?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: One last thing if you don't mind. May I?

content.body: don't ask to ask, just ask :)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: don't ask to ask, just ask :)

content.body: Thanks a lot. I don't find the style property in the WHATWG DOM standard. It's instead in the HTML standard. Why is this so? I guess that the style JavaScript property is also part of the DOM, then why does it get its place in the WHATWG HTML standard?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Thanks a lot. I don't find the style property in the WHATWG DOM standard. It's instead in the HTML standard. Why is this so? I guess that the style JavaScript property is also part of the DOM, then why does it get its place in the WHATWG HTML standard?

content.body: It's actually defined in CSSOM: https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-1/#the-elementcssinlinestyle-mixin
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It's actually defined in CSSOM: https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-1/#the-elementcssinlinestyle-mixin

content.body: But it could've been defined in the DOM standard, couldn't it? There must be some reason, that I am unaware of, due to which it was given place in the CSSOM standard?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: But it could've been defined in the DOM standard, couldn't it? There must be some reason, that I am unaware of, due to which it was given place in the CSSOM standard?

content.body: Yeah, but it would violate layering. Having HTML-specific things in DOM is also a layering violation, but HTML is less optional and more integrated. For the style attribute, DOM would have to put a dependency on CSS, HTML, SVG and MathML
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yeah, but it would violate layering. Having HTML-specific things in DOM is also a layering violation, but HTML is less optional and more integrated. For the style attribute, DOM would have to put a dependency on CSS, HTML, SVG and MathML

content.body: Alright.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Alright.

content.body: Can you elaborate this further : 'Having HTML-specific things in DOM is also a layering violation, but HTML is less optional and more integrated.'
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Can you elaborate this further : 'Having HTML-specific things in DOM is also a layering violation, but HTML is less optional and more integrated.'

content.body: Are you asking about what a layering violation is?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Are you asking about what a layering violation is?

content.body: Yeah.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yeah.

content.body: I think that it might be adding something where it ideally shouldn't be. Right?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think that it might be adding something where it ideally shouldn't be. Right?

content.body: I guess that including the style attribute in the DOM standard would've required the DOM standard to define a lot of CSS-specific interfaces, which would've simply cluttered the spec. Is that so?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I guess that including the style attribute in the DOM standard would've required the DOM standard to define a lot of CSS-specific interfaces, which would've simply cluttered the spec. Is that so?

content.body: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multitier_architecture
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multitier_architecture

content.body: The layering for the web is summarized in https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/introduction.html#abstract
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The layering for the web is summarized in https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/introduction.html#abstract

content.body: So basically including HTML in the DOM standard is a violation, but it can't be avoided completely. Is that what you mean?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: So basically including HTML in the DOM standard is a violation, but it can't be avoided completely. Is that what you mean?

content.body: The Freelancer: the DOM standard can be used outside the context of HTML, it's an API to manipulate a document in general. You can see HTML as expanding it with browser features, and the CSS spec enhancing it even more
content.formatted_body: The Freelancer: the DOM standard can be used outside the context of HTML, it's an API to manipulate a document in general. You can see HTML as expanding it with browser features, and the CSS spec enhancing it even more

content.body:
PSA: I’ve mentioned here before that I wrote a tool which generates activity reports for GitHub repos somewhat like the Pulse thing in GitHub itself, but in a lot more detail.

Today and yesterday I used it to generate and archive a bunch of reports for a bunch of different repos — including some WHATWG ones.

The ones I generated so far are at https://git-pulse.github.io/reports/
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text:
PSA: I’ve mentioned here before that I wrote a tool which generates activity reports for GitHub repos somewhat like the Pulse thing in GitHub itself, but in a lot more detail.

Today and yesterday I used it to generate and archive a bunch of reports for a bunch of different repos — including some WHATWG ones.

The ones I generated so far are at https://git-pulse.github.io/reports/
